prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N2997
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
targeting CO, CN, C17O D=11.24Mpc resolution=2.9" (3.7" corresponds to 200pc but larger than maximam), 5km/s
tint=12sec per pt -> 14mJy/b (150mK) can be achieved
67 pointings for 2.5'x4' -> 36 min in total 6'x4' with 149 pts -> ~58min

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Correlator configurations are set to detect the 12CO(1-0) line at 5 km/s resolution and to cover the entire velocity width (~300 km/s) of this galaxy. CN and C17O can be observed simultaneously.

The target size of 200 pc corresponds to 3.7" at this galaxy. Since this is larger than the angular resolution from the most compact configuration, we request the latter, i.e. 2.9". The requested largest angular scale corresponds to 500 pc, which is a typical width of spiral arms.

We aim to detect 10^6 Msun clouds with size of 200 pc and velocity width of 15 km/s. Assuming the Galactic conversion factor, the peak intensity is estimated to be ~0.6 K. For S/N>3 detection, a sensitivity of 0.2 K at 5 km/s width is necessary.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N1365
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
targeting CO, CN, C17O D=18.16Mpc resolution=2.3", 5km/s

We aim to detect 10^6 Msun clouds with size of 200 pc and velocity width of 15 km/s. Assuming the Galactic conversion factor, the peak intensity is estimated to be ~0.6 K. For S/N>3 detection, a sensitivity of 0.2 K at 5 km/s width is requested.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Correlator configurations are set to detect the 12CO(1-0) line at 5 km/s resolution and to cover the entire velocity width (~ 200 km/s) of this galaxy. CN and C17O can be simultaneously observed.

The target size of 200 pc corresponds to 5.2" at this galaxy. Since this is larger than the angular resolution from the most compact configuration, we request the latter, i.e. 2.9". The requested largest angular scale corresponds to 500 pc, which is a typical width of spiral arms.

We aim to detect 10^6 Msun clouds with size of 200 pc and velocity width of 15 km/s. Assuming the Galactic conversion factor, the peak intensity is estimated to be ~0.6 K. For S/N>3 detection, a sensitivity of 0.2 K at 5 km/s is requested.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose a pilot wide-field CO(1-0) mapping survey of nearby spiral galaxies at 200pc resolution with ALMA. The immediate goal of this pilot project is to apply the offset method, which derives the pattern speed and star formation timescale simulataneously by measuring offsets between CO and H-alpha. Using CO maps from existing surveys, we derived these two parameters for five northern spiral galaxies. Furthermore, we found possible correlations between the star formation timescale and other physical parameters such as gas column density and metallicity, which suggest the self gravity of molecular clouds and metal line cooling be a major driver of star formation processes. New CO maps of southern spiral galaxies will enable us to asses if these correlations are real or not, and thus provide important information on mechanisms controlling star formation. In addition, derived pattern speeds will help to understand the nature of the spiral structure in target galaxies. In future cycles, we plan to extend this project to a large survey of ~100 nearby galaxies. ALMA is the only instrument that can perform such a large and wide-field mapping survey with high resolution and sensitivity.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Division of Optical and Infrared Astronomy, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
